p: Advances resulting from clinical and experimental investigations have demonstrated that the microbiome might play a critical role in the pathogenesis of IBD [ 65, 66]. In parallel, results from other studies have supported a link between dietary patterns and the structure of the intestinal microbiome in healthy individuals and in patients with gastrointestinal disorders, including IBD [ 17, 27, 67]. Given the potential effects that diet can have on the composition and function of the intestinal microbiome, diet may also be involved in the pathogenesis of IBD, either directly or indirectly. As a consequence, due to the associations with the microbiome and IBD, specific dietary interventions are promising novel therapies.
